name: Montpellier
fun_fact: Fun fact: In 1787, a young American ambassador named Thomas Jefferson visited Montpellier and declared the wine of Saint-Georges d'Orques one of the best wines he'd tasted in France. When he became President of the United States, he served this Montpellier wine at the White House! The region has been making wine since 500 BC when Etruscans settled in nearby Lattesâ€”archaeologists even found an ancient grape-stomping trough proving wine trade existed 2,500 years ago.

hero_dishes.name: Brandade de Morue
hero_dishes.description: Salt cod purÃ©e whipped with olive oil, milk, and garlic into a creamy, rich spread. A Mediterranean specialty highlighting Montpellier's coastal connections.
hero_dishes.origin_story: This Languedoc classic dates back centuries as a preservation method for cod. The dish showcases the region's blend of French technique and Mediterranean ingredientsâ€”salt cod from the Atlantic, olive oil from the south.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional brasseries throughout Montpellier's historic center, especially those serving Languedoc-Roussillon specialties

hero_dishes.name: Brasucade de Moules
hero_dishes.description: Fresh Mediterranean mussels cooked over burning coals, giving them a distinctive smoky flavor. Often seasoned simply with herbs and white wine.
hero_dishes.origin_story: A rustic coastal tradition where fishermen would grill fresh mussels directly over wood fires on the beach. The charred, smoky preparation is uniquely Mediterranean French, distinct from the steamed moules-frites of Belgium.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Seafood restaurants near the coast and traditional Languedoc brasseries

hero_dishes.name: Fougasse Bread
hero_dishes.description: Montpellier's traditional flatbread, often studded with olives, herbs, or anchovies. Light, crispy, and deeply aromatic.
hero_dishes.origin_story: An ancient bread dating back to Roman times in Provence and Languedoc. Each region has its own version, and Montpellier's fougasse reflects the Mediterranean terroir with local olive oil and herbs.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Local boulangeries throughout the city, especially in the old town markets

hero_dishes.name: Oysters from Thau Lagoon

hero_dishes.origin_story: The Thau Lagoon has been cultivated for oysters since the late 19th century. These Mediterranean oysters have a distinctive minerality and sweetness compared to Atlantic varieties. Just 30km from Montpellier, they arrive at restaurants within hours of harvest.

signature_drinks.name: Muscat de Lunel
signature_drinks.description: A famous sweet, aromatic wine from the nearby Lunel region, made from Muscat grapes. Golden, honeyed, with intense floral notes.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served chilled as an aperitif or with desserts. This vin doux naturel (fortified wine) has been produced in the region for centuries and is a point of local pride.
